• anchor

    Image credit: Ave Pildas

    A new 12-part documentary series is set to premiere on July 1st, spotlighting a formative era in Los Angeles architecture. Produced by nonprofit FORT: LA and hosted by architectural journalist Frances Anderton, Rebel Architects: From Venice to the World Stage revisits the creative context of 1980s Venice Beach and the architects who helped shape its now-iconic West Coast design identity.

    The project draws inspiration from a 1980 portrait by photographer Ave Pildas, which captured seven young architects, Frederick Fisher, Robert Mangurian, Eric Owen Moss, Coy Howard, Craig Hodgetts, Thom Mayne, and Frank Gehry, at Venice Beach. Forty-five years later, four of those original subjects reunite for roundtable discussions and interviews reflecting on their careers, the architectural landscape of Los Angeles, and the evolution of the profession.

    Filmed in a relaxed and conversational style, Rebel Architects offers 6–15 minute episodes that chronicle the personal and professional journeys of its subjects, culminating in a re-creation of the original photograph by Pildas. New episodes will be released monthly via FORT: LA's website.

    The launch of the series will be accompanied by programming during the LA Design Festival and FORT: LA’s Architecture Uncorked series. In addition, FORT: LA has created a self-guided architecture trail titled The Rebel Architects of 1980, featuring early projects by key figures from the series. The 90-page guide leads visitors through six “exteriors only” sites across Los Angeles and celebrates the legacy of the city’s experimental and independent design culture.
